discussion.content: restricting access and a new user account sound like the most pausible solution here
I agree with A & D. The business isn't going to buy another COTS solution. It's a Band-Aid up what you can after the fact.

AD
Don't use a persons credentials, create credentials specifically for the developers to share.
Block access to everyone except the developers to minimize risk.
THE ANSWER IS AD. NEW COTS SOLUTION WILL DISRUPT SERVICE.

B. Implement a new COTS solution that does not use hard-coded credentials and integrates with directory services
D. Provision a new user account within the enterprise directory and enable its use for authentication to the target applications. Share the username and password with all developers for use in their individual scripts

comments.content: Wouldn't implementing a new cots solution disrupt the testing process?

choices.C: Obfuscate the username within the script file with encoding to prevent easy identification and the account used
choices.D: Provision a new user account within the enterprise directory and enable its use for authentication to the target applications. Share the username and password with all developers for use in their individual scripts
choices.A: Restrict access to the network share by adding a group only for developers to the share's ACL
choices.B: Implement a new COTS solution that does not use hard-coded credentials and integrates with directory services
choices.E: Redesign the web applications to accept single-use, local account credentials for authentication

questions.question_text: A software development team is conducting functional and user acceptance testing of internally developed web applications using a COTS solution. For automated testing, the solution uses valid user credentials from the enterprise directory to authenticate to each application. The solution stores the username in plain text and the corresponding password as an encoded string in a script within a file, located on a globally accessible network share. The account credentials used belong to the development team lead. To reduce the risks associated with this scenario while minimizing disruption to ongoing testing, which of the following are the BEST actions to take? (Choose two.)

During the migration of a company's human resources application to a PaaS provider, the Chief Privacy Officer (CPO) expresses concern the vendor's staff may be able to access data within the migrating application. The application stack includes a multitier architecture and uses commercially available, vendor-supported software packages. Which of the following BEST addresses the CPO's concerns?

discussion.content:
Maybe: B. Ensure the platform vendor implements data-at-rest encryption on its storage.
Since the concern is with the vendor's staff, it is unlikely they mainly concerned at data in transit. The vendor's staff has no more access to that than anybody else.

comments.content: "staff may be able to access data within the migrating application"

choices.B: Ensure the platform vendor implements data-at-rest encryption on its storage.
choices.D: Implement a CASB that tokenizes company data in transit to the migrated applications.
choices.C: Enable MFA to the vendor's tier of the architecture.
choices.A: Execute non-disclosure agreements and background checks on vendor staff.

discussion.content:
Seems like it's C:
How it works

A Bayesian filter works by comparing your incoming email with a database of emails, which are categorised into ‘spam’ and ‘not spam’.

Bayes’ theorem is used to learn from these prior messages. Then, the filter can calculate a spam probability score against each new message entering your inbox.

This “learning” process also happens on the fly. For example, every time you instruct the filter to spam or quarantine certain messages, it will incorporate that data into future actions.

So, the Bayesian filter will improve with time – even as spammers invent new ways to get their emails through.

Selected Answer: C
A & D already listed in current filtering, leaving options B & C.
C is a stronger option than B
deduction: C Correct Answer

Selected Answer: C
"A Bayesian filter is a program that uses Bayesian logic , also called Bayesian analysis, to evaluate the header and content of an incoming e-mail message and determine the probability that it constitutes spam."

What throws me off about option B is "per suspicious email." We have no idea how man suspicious emails they are getting. This could be VERY cumbersome.

questions.question_text:
The email administrator must reduce the number of phishing emails by utilizing more appropriate security controls. The following configurations already are in place:
✑ Keyword blocking based on word lists
✑ URL rewriting and protection
✑ Stripping executable files from messages
Which of the following is the BEST configuration change for the administrator to make?

choices.A: Configure more robust word lists for blocking suspicious emails.
choices.C: Configure Bayesian filtering to block suspicious inbound email.
choices.D: Configure the mail gateway to strip any attachments.
choices.B: Configure appropriate regular expression rules per suspicious email received.

discussion.content: netstat provided the connection status so B is correct

arp -s ... adds an static address
netstat -a query TCP/IP port usage and the state of socket connections., so B is the correct.
